Mechanism and optimization for oxidative desulfurization of fuels catalyzed by Fenton-like catalysts in hydrophobic ionic liquid Wei Jiang a Wenshuai Zhu a ⁎ Huaming Li a ⁎ Yanhong Chao a Suhang Xun a Yonghui Chang a Hui Liu a Zhen Zhao b a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Jiangsu University, Zhenjiang 212013, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Jiangsu University Zhenjiang 212013 PR China b State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum, Beijing 102249, PR China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum Beijing 102249 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Tel.: +86 511 88791800; fax: +86 511 88791708. Graphical abstract Dibenzothiophene (DBT) in model oil was first extracted into IL phase and oxidized to the corresponding sulfone by O2 −, which was generated by ChFeCl4 upon interaction with H2O2 in IL. Various Fenton-like catalysts prepared by choline chloride (ChCl) and metal salts (FeCl3, ZnCl2, SnCl2) were characterized by FT-IR, UV–vis, Raman, ESI-MS and elemental analysis. High desulfurization efficiency of dibenzothiophene (DBT) could be obtained not only in hydrophilic ionic liquid (IL) [Bmim]BF4 (94.9%) but also in hydrophobic IL [Omim]BF4 (97.2%) by using ChFeCl4 as a catalyst under mild conditions. ESR measurements could give the evidence that the active oxygen species generated by ChFeCl4 and H2O2 in IL were involved in the catalytic oxidation of DBT. The influential factors, including reaction time, temperature, catalyst dosage, and O/S (H2O2/DBT) molar ratio, were investigated in detail to estimate the optimal conditions for the desulfurization system in [Omim]BF4. The aromatic sulfur compounds, DBT, benzothiophene (BT), and 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT), could be oxidized to the corresponding sulfones, which were detected by GC–MS. Moreover, the catalytic system containing IL and catalyst could be easily separated from oil and could be recycled at least five times without a significant decrease on removal of DBT. Keywords Fenton-like Oxidative desulfurization Ionic liquid Electron spin resonance 1 Introduction In recent years, oxidative desulfurization (ODS) of fuels has attracted a great deal of attention due to its advantages, such as high efficiency and mild reaction conditions [1–5]. At the beginning, the sulfur compounds are firstly oxidized to sulfones, which are then removed by selective extraction with polar solvents, such as N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) [6], 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) [7,8], acetonitrile [9,10] and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) [11,12], methanol [13]. Although the ODS processes turn out to be effective, the extractants are usually flammable and volatile organic compounds (VOCs). The use of VOCs can lead to further environmental and safety concerns [14–16]. Therefore, ionic liquid (IL) may be a credible alternative to the VOCs. Nowadays room temperature ionic liquids (RTILs) have been widely investigated as “green” solvents [17–19]. It is known that they have various advantages, such as wide liquid range, negligible vapor pressure and high thermal stability, and they are not flammable [20–23]. Wei and the co-workers reported a desulfurization process by a combination of chemical oxidation and ionic liquids (ILs) extraction [12]. In this process, H2O2 and CH3COOH were employed in the oxidation of dibenzothiophene (DBT). Zhao and co-workers explored two kinds of ILs that were a coordinated IL C5H9NO·SnCl2 and Lewis acidic IL Me3NCH2C6H5Cl·2ZnCl2 [24,25]. The two ILs were used as extractants for ODS with H2O2 and CH3COOH as oxidants. In the above reports, the ODS with ionic liquid were all carried out in the presence of organic acids. To avoid using organic acids, a novel system of extraction and catalytic oxidative desulfurization (ECODS) was proposed in our previous work. In this system, deep desulfurization could be achieved by a combination of conventional ILs and different kinds of catalysts, such as the phosphotungstic acid [26], decatungstates [6], peroxo-molybdenum amino acid complexes [27], heteropolyanion-based ionic liquid [28], and V2O5 [29]. More importantly, organic acids have not been used in these processes. Therefore, ECODS system with a suitable catalyst is becoming a green and effective process. In general, Fe3+/H2O2 as one of the advanced oxidation systems used to be employed to treat a variety of industrial wastewater [30]. There are very few examples of the use of Fenton-like reagents in oxidative desulfurization. Dai et. al applied Fenton reagent in oxidative desulfurization of diesel fuel, however, the organic extractant DMF and organic acid CH3COOH were used in the process [31]. Recently, an ECODS system has been reported by our group, where Fenton-like reagent composed of FeCl3 and H2O2 could oxidize DBT to dibenzothiophene sulfone (DBTO2) in hydrophilic IL 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetraﬂuoroborate ([Bmim]BF4) [32]. However, FeCl3 possesses several drawbacks, such as difficulties in separation/recovery, environmental hazards and disposal problems [33]. Moreover, the desulfurization efficiency was poor in hydrophobic IL. We also reported another tetramethylammonium Fe-based catalyst for oxidative desulfurization in [Bmim]BF4 [34]. However, this experiment had to be carried out with a large amount of catalyst and oxidant. Furthermore, the oxidative mechanism of Fenton-like reagent has been widely studied in aqueous solution system but little researched in ionic liquid system, especially in oxidative desulfurization system. Therefore, more environmentally-friendly and efficient catalysts or catalytic systems should be explored for ECODS system, and it should be interesting to find out the oxidative mechanism in ionic liquid system. In this paper, a series of Fenton-like catalysts were synthesized from cheap materials, choline chloride and metal salts. Compared with our previous work, the new Fenton-like catalyst [(C2H4OH)N(CH3)3]FeCl4 (ChFeCl4) had high desulfurization capacity in hydrophilic IL [Bmim]BF4, and exhibited even higher activity in hydrophobic IL 1-n-octyl-3-methylimidazolium tetraﬂuoroborate ([Omim]BF4). Thus, this work may further develop the application field of Fenton-like catalysts from a biphasic system to a triphasic system. Furthermore, the oxidative desulfurization mechanism was investigated by adding hydroxyl radical scavengers and electron spin resonance (ESR) spin-trapping technique. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Benzothiophene (BT), DBT, and 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT) were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich. The conventional ionic liquids [Bmim]BF4 and [Omim]BF4 were purchased from Shanghai Chengjie Chemical Co., Ltd. Other materials were commercial reagent grade and were obtained from Shanghai Sinopharm Chemical Co., Ltd. Model oils were prepared by dissolving DBT, BT and 4,6-DMDBT in n-octane to give solutions with a sulfur content of 500, 250 and 250ppm, respectively. In addition, tetradecane was added into the model oil as an internal standard. 2.2 Preparation of the Fenton-like catalysts Under vigorous stirring, anhydrous FeCl3 (1.62g, 0.01mol) was dissolved in absolute ethyl alcohol (50mL), and an alcohol solution of stoichiometric quantity choline chloride (1.40g, 0.01mol) was added at room temperature. The mixture was then reacted for 4h. Then a yellow solid ChFeCl4 was obtained by evaporating the solvent under reduced pressure and washed with diethyl ether (3×10mL). The syntheses of (Ch)2ZnCl4 and ChSnCl3 were similar to the above process. However, two white precipitates could be formed instantaneously after mixing the alcohol solution of ChCl (0.01mol) with that of ZnCl2 (0.01mol) or SnCl2 (0.01mol). All the catalysts were dried in vacuum at 40°C for 24h. Data for ChFeCl 4: Elemental analysis calcd (%): C 19.90, H 4.68, N 4.64, found: C 20.07, H 4.58, N 4.53. Raman (cm−1): 3030, 2974, 2924, 1444, 712, 334, 110; ESI-MS: Ch+ 104.0, [FeCl4]− 197.7. Data for (Ch) 2 ZnCl 4: Elemental analysis calcd (%): C 28.90, H 6.79, N 6.74, found: C 28.79, H 7.15, N 6.60. Raman (cm−1): 1191, 1084, 1071, 1022, 988, 626, 422, 278, 220; ESI-MS: Ch+ 104.1, [ChCl[ZnCl4]]2− 173.9. Data for ChSnCl 3: Elemental analysis calcd (%): C 18.24, H 4.29, N 4.25, found: C 17.98, H 4.09, N 4.46. Raman (cm−1): 3030, 2973, 2922, 1449, 715, 953, 308, 159; ESI-MS: Ch+ 104.0, [SnCl3]− 224.7. 2.3 Characterization and analysis The FT-IR spectra of all the catalysts (KBr pellets) were recorded with a Nicolet Nexus 470 FT-IR instrument. Ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) spectra were performed on UV-2450 spectrophotometer (Shimadzu Corporation, Japan). Electrospray ionization mass (ESI-MS) spectra were collected on a LXQ Linear Ion Trap Mass Spectrometer. Raman tests were carried out by using Thermo Scientific DXR Smart Raman spectrometer equipped with a 532nm excitation. Elementary analyses were performed with CHN-O-Rapid (Heraeus Corporation). X-band ESR spectra were recorded at ambient temperature on a JES FA200 spectrometer. The settings for the ESR spectrometer were as follows: center field, 336.496mT; sweep width, 5mT; microwave frequency, 9.5GHz; modulation frequency, 100kHz; power, 0.998mW. 2.4 Oxidative desulfurization procedure In a typical reaction run, 0.03g (0.1mmol) ChFeCl4, 1mL of conventional IL and 5mL of model oil were added into a two-necked flask. Then 0.042mL H2O2 (11.34molL−1) was injected to the flask after extraction for 10min. The mixture was stirred for 1h at room temperature under atmospheric pressure. From the phenomena, catalyst could dissolve in IL but hardly in model oil. H2O2 solution could not dissolve in [Omim]BF4 or model oil. Therefore, the reaction system was a triphasic system, where the lowest layer was the IL and catalyst, H2O2 solution was in the middle and the oil phase was the upper layer. So the model oil was separated by decantation after reaction for further analysis via gas chromatography-ﬂame ionization detection (GC-FID) (Agilent 7890A, HP-5 column, 30m long×0.32mm inner diameter (id)×0.25μm film thickness). The sulfur removal was calculated as in Eq. (1), where C 0 (ppm) is the initial sulfur concentration in the model oil, C t (ppm) is the transient sulfur concentration at any time t (min). (1) Sulfur removal ( % ) = 1 − C t C 0 × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the Fenton-like catalysts The FT-IR spectra of ChFeCl4, (Ch)2ZnCl4 and ChSnCl3 are shown in Fig. 1 . The absorption bands in the range of 3200–3500cm−1 can be ascribed to stretching vibration of hydroxyl groups (OH). The bands in the range of 2800–3000cm−1 come from the stretching vibration of CH3 and CH2 . The characteristic peaks at 1475 and 1416cm−1 are due to the bending vibration of CH. The peak at 1084cm−1 and the shoulder peak around 1047cm−1 can be assigned to CO and CN vibrations, respectively. Compared with the FT-IR spectra of ChCl, the characteristic peaks at 1404cm−1 and 1093cm−1 shifted to 1416cm−1 and 1084cm−1, respectively, which may be attributed to the effect of Fenton-like catalysts anion. Therefore, it could be concluded that the cations of the three Fenton-like catalysts are derived from the material ChCl. To confirm the anion species, UV–vis spectra of the Fenton-like catalysts are collected from 200 to 800nm (Fig. 2 ). The spectrum of ChFeCl4 is measured in acetonitrile. ChFeCl4 shows the three characteristic bands of the [FeCl4]− ion at 246, 316 and 364nm and agrees with previous literature [35]. The diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) of (Ch)2ZnCl4 and ChSnCl3 are recorded at room temperature according to the literature [36–38]. The absorption curve (Fig. 2) of (Ch)2ZnCl4 is consistent with that reported in literature [36], indicating the ZnCl4 2− anion. There is only one band at 226nm for ChSnCl3, assigning to tetrahedral Sn species, i.e. SnCl3 − [37,38]. 3.2 Investigation of the different desulfurization systems The oxidation of DBT was performed under atmospheric pressure to select the best desulfurization system. In the desulfurization process, ILs were used as extractants and a small excess of H2O2 was the oxidant. DBT was firstly extracted into the IL phase and then was oxidized to the corresponding sulfone. As shown in Table 1 , the extraction rates of the two ILs, hydrophilic [Bmim]BF4 and hydrophobic [Omim]BF4, were 20.4% and 36.8%, respectively. When H2O2 solution was added, the removal of DBT decreased either in [Bmim]BF4 or in [Omim]BF4, which might be ascribed to the fact that the H2O2 solution into ILs phase made some extracted DBT to return to the oil phase [22]. When (Ch)2ZnCl4 and ChSnCl3 were used as catalysts in IL, the oxidative desulfurization efficiency were lower than extractive desulfurization, which indicated that the two catalysts could not activate H2O2 to oxidize DBT. However, when ChFeCl4 was in conjunction with H2O2 and IL, the sulfur removal increased sharply, reaching 89.9% ([Bmim]BF4) and 97.2% ([Omim]BF4), respectively. In the absence of IL, the three Fenton-like catalysts showed quite low catalytic activities. These experiments clearly demonstrated the ECODS was superior to mere extraction with IL as well as the extractive oxidation without catalyst or the catalytic oxidation without IL. In addition, the different sulfur removals in the two ionic liquids might be attributed to the different extractive ability of [Omim]BF4 and [Bmim]BF4. Thereby, a natural conclusion could be easily drawn that the desulfurization system containing ChFeCl4, [Omim]BF4 and H2O2 was the best system in this work. Another result showed that the sulfur removal increased to 94.9% in [Bmim]BF4 at 60min. Thus, deep desulfurization in hydrophilic [Bmim]BF4 was also feasible. It is instructive to compare the catalytic oxidative removal of DBT by ECODS system with Fe-based catalysts. In our previous work, the commercially available FeCl3 served as catalyst and exhibited 96.1% sulfur removal in the hydrophilic IL [Bmim]BF4 at 4h, however, it showed low activity in the hydrophobic IL [Omim]BF4 (72.2%) [32]. The new Fenton-like catalyst ChFeCl4 in this work had high catalytic activity not only in the hydrophilic IL but also in the hydrophobic IL. Moreover, the reaction time was shortened obviously from 4h to 0.5h. Thus, this work could extend the application area and might have a good application prospect. Our group also reported a catalyst [(CH3)4N]FeCl4 on oxidative desulfurization in hydrophilic IL [Bmim]BF4 [34]. However, this experiment had to be carried out with a large amount of catalyst (catalyst/DBT molar ratio=2.5) and oxidant (H2O2/DBT molar ratio=11.6) and H2O2 in this system was decomposed severely (48% H2O2 was decomposed). In contrast, deep oxidative desulfurization of DBT catalyzed by ChFeCl4 in [Omim]BF4 could be accomplished in 30min at room temperature, which is, to the best of our knowledge, one of the most efficient systems using ionic liquids reported so far. Moreover, the reaction mechanism in previous work was ambiguous or ultimately speculated. 3.3 The mechanism of ECODS system with ChFeCl4 as catalyst in [Omim]BF4 Fenton or Fenton-like reagents have been proved to be an effective technology for the treatment of industrial wastewater, in which strong oxidizing species such as OH are generated to degrade diverse organic compounds with nonselective reactivity [30]. The generation of other oxidizing species, such as O2 − and high-valent iron species (FeIV =O), has also been proposed in the aqueous solution system [39–41]. However, there are few literatures that have determined the active oxidizing species in ionic liquid desulfurization system by an experimental way. Thus, it is necessary to clarify the main active oxidizing species that made a major contribution in the system of this work. In order to investigate whether hydroxyl radical was involved in the present reaction. A desulfurization experiment on removal of DBT was carried out by the addition of some hydroxyl radical scavengers such as NaHCO3, KBr, tert-butanol and isopropanol in IL. From the results listed in Table 2 , it could be seen that the sulfur removal was almost not inﬂuenced by the additional OH scavengers with equimolar quantities of DBT. When more OH scavengers (mole ratio of scavengers and DBT was 5) were put into the desulfurization system, there was still no significant decrease on the oxidation of DBT. Therefore, it could be deduced that OH might not be the main active oxidizing species. To further confirm the active species, ESR measurements with the spin trap 5,5′-dimethyl-1-pirroline-N-oxide (DMPO) were carried out to detect the active oxidizing species in the system. It is known that a characteristic DMPO-OH spin adduct with four-line peaks (a N = a H =14.9G) is attributed to the formation of the hydroxyl radical. Therefore, the weak ESR signal detected in Fig. 3a before adding H2O2 might be ascribed to a small amount of DMPO-OH adduct because hydroxyl groups of ChFeCl4 might be trapped by DMPO to form the DMPO-OH adduct [30]. After additional H2O2, a strong DMPO-O2 − signal (a N =14.4 G, a H =13.9G) was observed in Fig. 3b, showing that O2 − was generated in the desulfurization system [41]. Thus, it was confirmed that O2 − was the the main active oxidizing species but OH was not. The fact that OH was not the main active oxidizing species on the oxidation of DBT could also be supported by another experiment. When the additional water (V(IL)/V(water)=1) was introduced into the desulfurization system containing the Fenton-like catalyst ChFeCl4, H2O2 and [Omim]BF4, the characteristic peaks of DMPO-OH were obviously observed (Fig. 4 ), but the DMPO-O2 − signal disappeared. This was possibly due to the fact that O2 − was unstable in the aqueous solution and was easily decomposed into OH. The desulfurization of DBT was evaluated in this condition and the sulfur removal was only 29.1%, which was much lower than that in the desulfurization system without the additional water. From all of the above results, it could be deduced that DBT was virtually oxidized by O2 −, which was the main active oxidizing species in the desulfurization system. 3.4 Oxidative desulfurization of model oil 3.4.1 Influence of the amount of ChFeCl4 and H2O2 on ECODS of DBT The amount of ChFeCl4 and H2O2 had a great inﬂuence on ECODS of DBT. The desulfurization system containing ChFeCl4, H2O2 and [Omim]BF4 was used to investigate the effect of different amounts of catalyst. As shown in Fig. 5 , when the amount of catalyst increased from 5mg to 30mg, the sulfur removal increased remarkably from 53.6% to 97.2%. The result indicated that the amount of catalyst in the reaction had a significant effect on removal of DBT. In order to study the inﬂuence of the amount of H2O2 on ECODS of DBT, various H2O2/sulfur (O/S) molar ratios were investigated in Fig. 6 . According to the stoichiometric reaction, 2mol H2O2 are consumed for oxidation of 1mol DBT to their corresponding sulfone (DBTO2). When the O/S molar ratio increased from 2:1 to 6:1, the removal of DBT from the model oil increased from 80.2% to 97.2%. Thus, the O/S molar ratio 6:1 was the optimal choice to achieve deep desulfurization. 3.4.2 Influence of the temperature and time on ECODS of DBT In order to evaluate the role of the temperature and time on the reaction efficiency, the oxidation of DBT was performed in ECODS system at 30°C, 40°C and 50°C. From Table 3 , the sulfur removal decreased in the order 30°C>40°C>50°C, and the decompostion of H2O2 followed the order 50°C>40°C>30°C. Thus, the higher temperature meant more decompostion of H2O2, which led to lower sulfur removal. However, in the first 10min in Fig. 7 , sulfur removal at 40°C was better than that at 30°C and 50°C. It could be explained that 40°C performed a positive influence on ECODS of DBT at the beginning 10min, but the final sulfur removal (92.5%) was lower than that at 30°C (97.2%) due to the more decomposition of H2O2 at 40°C. Therefore, 30°C was more suitable for this system. For the reaction time, sulfur removal increased rapidly at the initial stage but slowly from 96.3% in 25min to 97.2% in 30min. Thus, it was suitable to carry out the desulfurization reaction at 30°C in 30min. 3.4.3 Sulfur removal of different sulfur-containing compounds In the foregoing experiments, the catalytic system containing Fenton-like catalyst ChFeCl4 and [Omim]BF4 showed high catalytic activity for ECODS of DBT. In order to study the catalytic activity of the catalytic system on other sulfur-containing compounds, BT and 4,6-DMDBT were chosen as the representative sulfur compounds. As seen from Fig. 8 , the removal of BT and 4,6-DMDBT could reach 86.9% and 72.8% in 30min, respectively. The results were much lower than the removal of DBT (97.2%) in 30min. These different reactivities of the three sulfur-containing compounds could be ascribed to Nernst partition coefﬁcient (K N) as well as their electron density and the steric hindrance around the sulfur atoms [11,42–44]. From the data in Table 4 , the electron density of 4,6-DMDBT (5.760) was higher than that of DBT and BT, but the K N was lowest in the three substrates and the steric hindrance of the methyl groups might be an obstacle for the sulfur atom to the approach active species. Therefore, the desulfurization efﬁciency of 4,6-DMDBT was the lowest. The K N and electron density of BT were lower than that of DBT, which led to the low desulfurization efficiency of BT. Therefore, the final reactivity of the three sulfur-containing compounds was in the following order: DBT>BT>4,6-DMDBT. 3.4.4 Oxidation products The oxidation products of sulfur species were not detected in oil phase, but existed in the ILs phase. This result was due to the different chemical polarity between products and model oil. After the reaction, the ILs phase was separated and extracted with carbon tetrachloride (CCl4). The products could be measured by GC–MS analysis of the CCl4 solution. As shown in Fig. 9a, the mass spectrum of the product shows the molecular ion peak at m/z 216.0 for oxidation product of DBT, which is assigned to corresponding sulfone DBTO2. Similar oxidation products of BT and 4,6-DMDBT were obtained and the mass spectra in Fig. 9b and c matched those of BTO2 (166.0) and 4,6-DMDBTO2 (246.0). 3.4.5 Recycling of the catalytic system containing ChFeCl4 and [Omim]BF4 As an efficient catalytic system, the cycle property was an important factor and was necessary to be investigated. After the first reaction run, the model oil was separated easily by decantation. The IL phase was distilled at 110°C for 3h to evaporate the residual H2O2, H2O and model oil. Then fresh H2O2 and model oil were added for the next run under the same conditions. The results in Fig. 10 showed that the removal of DBT could still reach 90.0% after being recycled for five times. In this process, the increasing oxidation product DBTO2 was accumulated in IL phase, which might lead to the gradual decrease of sulfur removal [32]. The used ChFeCl4/[Omim]BF4 and the fresh ChFeCl4/[Omim]BF4 were characterized by the Raman spectra in Fig. 11 . The same characteristic peaks of FeCl4 − at 333cm−1 were obtained, which indicated that this catalyst was stable during the desulfurization process. 4 Conclusion The Fenton-like catalysts have been synthesized and used for the oxidation of different sulfur compounds. Among the three catalysts, ChFeCl4 showed the best activity on desulfurization of DBT. Under the optimal reaction conditions, 94.9% and 97.2% removal of DBT could be obtained in [Bmim]BF4 and [Omim]BF4, respectively, when using ChFeCl4 as a catalyst. The oxidation reactivity of different substrates was in the following order: DBT>BT>4,6-DMDBT. It has been demonstrated that hydroxyl radical was not the the main active oxidizing species on the oxidation of DBT because hydroxyl radical traps had a slight impact on desulfurization. Using ESR spectroscopy with spin traps DMPO, DMPO-O2 − has been detected in the desulfurization system. The desulfurization experiment with additional water may further indicated that hydroxyl radical could not oxidize DBT in the system. Through the GC–MS analysis, the three aromatic sulfur compounds could be oxidized to form the corresponding sulfones. The catalytic system containing IL and catalyst could be easily separated and recycled for five times. coredata.dc:description: Various Fenton-like catalysts prepared by choline chloride (ChCl) and metal salts (FeCl3, ZnCl2, SnCl2) were characterized by FT-IR, UV–vis, Raman, ESI-MS and elemental analysis. High desulfurization efficiency of dibenzothiophene (DBT) could be obtained not only in hydrophilic ionic liquid (IL) [Bmim]BF4 (94.9%) but also in hydrophobic IL [Omim]BF4 (97.2%) by using ChFeCl4 as a catalyst under mild conditions. ESR measurements could give the evidence that the active oxygen species generated by ChFeCl4 and H2O2 in IL were involved in the catalytic oxidation of DBT. The influential factors, including reaction time, temperature, catalyst dosage, and O/S (H2O2/DBT) molar ratio, were investigated in detail to estimate the optimal conditions for the desulfurization system in [Omim]BF4. The aromatic sulfur compounds, DBT, benzothiophene (BT), and 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT), could be oxidized to the corresponding sulfones, which were detected by GC–MS. Moreover, the catalytic system containing IL and catalyst could be easily separated from oil and could be recycled at least five times without a significant decrease on removal of DBT.
coredata.dc:title: Mechanism and optimization for oxidative desulfurization of fuels catalyzed by Fenton-like catalysts in hydrophobic ionic liquid
